newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks close sharply higher across the board.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks close sharply higher across the board.

text.p: Stocks closed Wednesday sharply higher on a techncial rebound, combined with renewed hopes for an early rise in the foreign ownership ceiling, brokers said.

The market's early rise was in reaction to the six straight days of falls until Monday. In the afternoon, a news report the government would soon announce the foreign stock ownership ceiling expansion fuelled broad-based buying.
But the U.S. Federal Reserve's increase of its short-term interest rate had no major impact.
The composite stock index jumped 2.77 percent, or 17.72 points, to close at 656.62.

"This is basically a technical rebound after the market's sharp drops last week," said broker Lim Chong-woo of Ssangyong Investment and Securities. "Buying orders in a lack of selling led to the big rises today and yesterday."
Out of 695 gainers, 169 stocks went to daily upper limits.
But brokers cautioned as they saw a strong selling force awaiting at around the 670-point level.
"Considering the economic fundamentals, the market is expected to see a downward correction very soon," said analyst Yoo Nam-gil of Hyundai Securities.
Petrochemicals rose on expectations that falling naphtha prices and rising export demand would help improve earnings of petrochemical makers.
Honam Petrochemical Corp ended 900 won higher at its daily limit of 13,300. Hanwha Chemical Corp also ended at its upper limit of 8,680 won by gaining 640 won.
"Although there remain some variables, falling naphtha prices will be a big help for their earnings this year," analyst William Ryoo of LG Securities said.
Chipmakers also gained on news reports that memory chip prices were recovering from last year's slump.
Hyundai Electronics Industries Co closed 2,100 won higher at 38,800 and LG Semicon Co rose 100 won to 28,000.
But Samsung Electronics ended 500 won lower at 60,000 won on quick profit-taking after having risen to a day high of 61,500 won.
The index futures June contracts rose 0.90 points to 63.90 and the underlying KOSPI-200 index added 1.91 points to 66.90.
